Dear Ms. Calcaterra:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention; prohibited
Title restraints; elimination of restraints
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159
Section (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
Description manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth's behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth's
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 1/27/2025 youth was improperly restrained by staff. Staff
placed youth in a chokehold with his arm for about one to two
minutes.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
January 30, 2025, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker.
Youth A said he has been placed at Children’s Village for three
weeks. Youth A said he was restrained by Staff 1 in the cafeteria
due to getting in a fight with Youth C. Youth A said Staff 1 grabbed
him around the neck with one arm and his other hand was holding
Youth A’s shirt over his stomach area. Youth A said Staff 1 walked
him into another room and then let go of his shirt however kept his
hand near Youth A’s neck. Youth A denied Staff 1 choking him or
ever feeling out of breath during the restraint. Youth A said Staff 1
was “just doing his job to stop the situation”. Youth A said he
walked the entire way and denied his feet leaving the floor. Youth
A said he feels safe at Children’s Village and does not have any
concerns with the way Staff 1 handled the incident.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
January 30, 2025, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker.
Youth B said he was in the cafeteria when Youth A got in a fight
with Youth C. Youth B said Staff 4 and Staff 5 restrained Youth C
and turned him away from Youth A. Youth B said Staff 1 grabbed
Youth A with his arms around Youth A’s chest and Youth A’s arms
down by his side and walked him out of the cafeteria and into the
media room. Youth B said Staff 1 was not upset and moved very
quickly. Youth B said Youth A was yelling at the other resident
while being moved into the media center and did not appear to be
out of breath. Youth B denied ever seeing Staff 1’s arm around
2

Youth A’s neck. Youth B said he has been placed at Children’s
Village for two years and has not had any concerns with Staff 1.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on January
30, 2025, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Staff 1 said
he has worked for Children’s Village for 29 years and is currently
working in J-Down. Staff 1 said he was with his group at lunch in
the BTS cafeteria. Youth A asked to clear his lunch and walked
over to Youth C and hit him over the head with his tray. Staff 1
said he grabbed Youth A around the “shoulders and chest” and
moved him to the media area due to Youth C trying to come
towards him. Staff 1 said once in the media area he released his
hold. Staff 1 said Staff 4 and Staff 5 were present and restrained
Youth C. Staff 1 said Staff 3 had been using the bathroom and
when she returned, she held the media door open for him to walk
through however he is unsure if she followed him into the media
room or not, stating she did not help in the restraint. Staff 1 said
Youth A was not struggling so he had his hand on Youth A’s chest
until Staff 2 arrived at which time he took his hand off Youth A.
Staff 1 said there is no training or CPI technique to break up a
fight. Staff 1 said they are trained to use Child Control Position for
a one-person restraint, noting Youth A is “too big” for that position.
Staff 1 said the CPI transport is with two staff however they did not
have the second staff available in that situation so to minimize
safety risk he moved Youth A alone. Staff 1 said after the situation
he was sent home due to not using the CPI positions. Staff 1
denied ever placing Youth A in a chokehold and said he was
holding Youth A from behind with his arms around his chest. Staff
1 said his arm was never around Youth A’s neck. Staff 1 said he
never picked Youth A up off the ground during the restraint. Staff 1
said Youth A never said he could not breathe or that he was
injured. Staff 1 noted Youth A has asthma which causes him to
have breathing issues which he is very vocal about so felt he
would have said something if he was having issues breathing
during the incident.
A Zoom meeting was held with Staff 1 on February 10, 2025, in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. During this meeting the video
footage was shared with Staff 1. Staff 1 said he did not realize
Youth A’s feet had left the ground. Staff 1 said he was trying to
end the incident as quickly as possible and did not have any
malicious intent when restraining him. Staff 1 reiterated staff do
not receive proper training to break up a fight or move a youth
alone.
3

Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on January
30, 2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 said he
is a float staff and arrived in the media center after the incident in
the cafeteria. Staff 2 said he helped Staff 1 transport Youth A from
the media center to behavior support intervention area. Staff 2
said when he arrived in the media center Youth A and Staff 1 were
standing in the corner however, he could not remember what body
position they were in. Staff 2 said neither Staff 1 nor Youth A
seemed upset at that point. Staff 2 denied Youth A being injured
or complaining of any injury. Staff 2 said he has worked with Staff
1 for several years and has never had any concerns with his
interactions with the youth. Staff 2 said the staff are trained to use
CPI when physically intervening with youth. Staff 2 denied any
holds that included hand or arm placement around a youth’s chest
or neck.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on January
30, 2025, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 said she
has worked at Children’s Village for twelve years and is a float
staff. Staff 3 said she was walking through the media center to the
bathroom when she saw Youth A struggling against Staff 1’s hold.
Staff 3 said she radioed “code 2” and ran over to the door and
held it open as Staff 1 walked through with Youth A. Staff 3 said
she remembers Staff 1 being behind Youth A however was not
able to remember where his hands were positioned. Staff 3 said
her immediate concern was for the youth in the cafeteria as there
were two youth recently placed that were friends with Youth C and
she wanted to make sure they did not involve themselves or that
the incident turn into a bigger issue. Staff 3 said she was worked
almost daily with Staff 1 for the past five years and has never had
concerns with his interactions with the youth. Staff 3 said she has
seen Staff 1 restrain youth and has never had concerns about the
restraints. Staff 3 said there is no training on how to break up a
fight other than try to separate the youth or use CPI restraints.
Staff 3 said the one-person restraint is a child control hold
however is difficult to do at times depending on the youth. Staff 3
denied seeing Staff 1 with his arm around Youth A’s neck, stating
his arm was around his chest or upper stomach area. Staff 3 said
Youth A was not injured from the incident. Staff 3 said Youth A
has asthma and has complained before about his breathing so felt
he would have notified staff if he was unable to breath during or
after the incident.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on February 4, 2025, in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 4 said he was in the
kitchen with Staff 5 when he heard a commotion and came into
4

the dining area. Staff 4 said he and Staff 5 immediately separated
Youth C and placed him in a two-person restraint. Staff 4 said he
knew Staff 1 had control of Youth A however he did not see the
intervention or restraint as he had his back towards them. Staff 4
said they are not trained in what to do in a fight and staff usually
try to get in-between the youth and if possible, remove the youth
from the area. Staff 4 said he has worked with Staff 1 for six years
and has never had any concerns with his interactions with the
youth.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on February 4, 2025, in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 5 said he was
restraining Youth C with Staff 4 and had his back to Staff 1 and
Youth A so did not see the restraint. Staff 5 said he has worked
with Staff 1 for sixteen years and does not have any concerns
about his interactions with youth. Staff 5 said there is no training
on how to break up a fight between youth. Staff 5 said they are
trained in CPI for restraints however that does not address
breaking up fights. Staff 5 said staff attempt to get in-between
youth to stop them from fighting however it can be difficult at times
to get the youth into a hold when they are so out of control.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
January 30, 2025, in collaboration with the MDHHS Worker.
Supervisor said she has worked with Staff 1 for over twenty years
and is currently the supervisor of J-Down. Supervisor said she
was not present during the incident however reviewed the footage
afterwards. Supervisor said Staff 1 is a “solid staff” and is focused
on “keeping everyone safe”. Supervisor said after review of the
video she noted the staff should have noticed Youth A kept his
tray after clearing his spot and got to him prior to the situation.
Supervisor said Staff 1, Staff 4 and Staff 5 all separated the youth
which was appropriate. Supervisor said Staff 1 should have used
or attempted to use the “emergency child control position” or hold
him and wait for other staff. Supervisor said it was concerning that
Staff 1 pulled him close and had him around the chest and picked
him up off the ground twice. Supervisor said the training does not
include the techniques that Staff 1 used during the incident.
Supervisor said it is staff judgement call on if they are to move a
youth alone. Supervisor said it is not against protocol to move a
youth alone. Supervisor reiterated what she reviewed on video is
“out of character” for him.
Administrator was interviewed via telephone on February 26,
2025. Administrator said he is one of the trainers for Crisis
Prevention Institute and trains non-violent crisis interventions to
5

staff. Administrator said all staff are trained in CPI which goes
over different positions and techniques to break up a fight.
Administrator said they are taught these techniques and role play
scenarios on how to use them. Administrator said staff are never
taught to place their arm around a youth’s neck or chest.
Administrator said using turn away or lever would have been
appropriate to move Youth A and then place him in a Child Control
restraint to ensure he did not continue to engage in the fight.
Video Review:
Video footage of January 27, 2025, BTS cafeteria was
reviewed on February 3, 2025. Staff 3 is seen leaving the dining
hall, Staff 1 is seen sitting in a chair facing the youth sitting at
dining room tables, and Youth A is seen taking his tray to the
trash. Youth A grabs a washcloth and takes his tray back to his
table as he wipes the table off. Youth A is seen holding his empty
tray in front of him with his hands on either side of it, walks behind
Youth C and hits him on the back of the head. He then begins to
swing his arms at Youth C repeatedly. Youth C gets up and
begins to kick and punch Youth A, at the same time Staff 1 is seen
immediately getting up and running over to Youth A and Youth C.
Staff 4 and Staff 5 are seen running out of the kitchen doorway
and placing Youth C in a restraint with both of their backs to Staff
1 and Youth A. Staff 1 takes ahold of Youth A from behind with his
arms around Youth A’s arms and chest/stomach as they are bent
over. Staff 1 stands upright, and his left arm is around Youth A’s
neck and his right hand is holding Youth A’s shirt on his stomach.
Staff 1 turns Youth A away from Youth C and begins to walk
across the dining room. Youth A’s feet leave the ground as they
walk two different times. Staff 3 is seen coming out of the media
center door as Staff 1 and Youth A approach. Staff 3 holds the
door for Staff 1 and Youth A to walk through and then goes to the
dining room floor and appears to be talking to the other youth.
Video footage of January 27, 2025, Media Room was reviewed
on January 30, 2025. Staff 1 and Youth A are seen entering the
room. Staff 1 is behind Youth A with his arm around Youth A’s
neck. Staff 1 continues to hold Youth A for several seconds. Staff
2 and another supervisor arrive, and Staff 1 releases his hold.
Documents Reviewed:
• Oakland County Children’s Village Policy Emergency
Restraint was reviewed. The policy outlines when staff are
allowed to use emergency restraint with youth stating they
must use “Non-Violent Crisit Intervention” through Crisis
Prevention Institute.
6

• Staff 1’s personnel file: There was discipline from May 10,
2017, for Staff to Resident Ratio due to lack of supervision.
Staff 1 completed the required CPI training on March 21,
2024.
• Youth A’s Incident Report dated January 27, 2025, which is
consistent with staff interviews. The incident report also
notes medical examination which noted he bit his lower lip
and no other injuries were noted.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per Youth A’s interview
and video review, Staff 1 did not use the approved restraint
technique when intervening with Youth A. Staff 1 had his arm
around Youth A’s chest/neck throughout the restraint, and when
transporting him out of the dining room picked Youth A up off the
ground.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance is offered for the agency to retrain staff on
CPI as it specifically relates to youth fighting and how to
successfully separate youth, as many staff stated they are not
trained properly on how to break up youth fighting. It is also
recommended to review the restraint videos with staff as a training
tool to discuss which restraint techniques would be appropriate to
utilize in different situations.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
